questions.text: Ulceration of the vulva is commonly seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vulval ulcers are predominantly due to sexually transmitted diseases and not to Bacterial vaginosis.

  • Rarely, it may be due to non-specific causes.
  • Malignant ulcers are also rare.
  • The various etiological factors related to vulvar ulcers are given in the table below.

Explanation:

Normal vaginal pH ranges from 3.5 - 4.5

Vagina has local inhabitant bacteria called as Doderlein's bacillus (lactobacilli) which breaks down the glycogen present in vaginal epithelium into lactic acid resulting in acidic pH (Avg, 4.5; Range, 4-5.5) of vagina.

The acidic pH of vagina acts as a barrier for external organisms.

Physiological Discharge

  • Clear, white, and flocculent odourless discharge
  • Smear contains epithelial cells, lactobacilli

questions.text: Which kind of epithelium is present in vagina?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In adult females, vagina is lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

  • In newborn females, it is lined by transitional epithelium.
  • Squamous epithelium is resistant to gonococcal infection.
  • Thus, gonococcal vaginitis cannot occur in young/adult females.

The epithelium of the vagina consists of multiple layers of flat cells.

questions.text: The most common gynaecological problem in prepubertal girls is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common gynaecological problem in prepubertal girls is vulvovaginitis.

Vulvovaginitis occurs due to a lack of estrogen, most commonly seen in children.

Causes

  • Foreign body
  • Worm infestation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Infections such as candida

Symptoms

  • Intense pruritus
  • Offensive vaginal discharge

Management

  • Estrogen cream

questions.text: All are the risk factors for sexually transmitted disease except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

High socioeconomic class is not a risk factor for sexually transmitted diseases.

Risk Factors for STIs/ Chlamydia Infection

  • History of previous STIs (Option B)
  • Contact with an infected person
  • Sexually active individual <25 years of age
  • Multiple partners (Option A)
  • New partner in the last 3 months
  • Not using barrier protection
  • Street involvement (homelessness, drug use). (Option C)
  • Low socioeconomic status

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman on treatment for rheumatoid arthritis presents with intense vulval pruritus and curdy white vaginal discharge. On examination, vaginal pH is <4.5. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Candida vaginal infection (Candidal vulvovaginitis) typically occurs in an acidic vaginal pH (<4.5), which differentiates it from other infections like bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis that occur in alkaline pH.

This patient with rheumatoid arthritis is likely on steroids or immunosuppressants, predisposing her to Candida infection.

It is common in individuals with:

  • Pregnancy
  • Diabetes
  • Immunosuppression
  • Antibiotic use
  • OCP or steroid use

Symptoms: Intense vulval itching, burning, dyspareunia, curdy white discharge

Signs: Thick "cottage cheese-like" discharge, normal cervix

Diagnosis:

  • 10% KOH pre-shows pseudohyphae or budding yeast
  • Sabouraud's dextrose agar - fungal culture

Treatment:

  • Clotrimazole vaginal pessary
  • Fluconazole 150 mg oral single dose

questions.text: The most common cause of pelvic inflammatory disease is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PID is most commonly caused by chlamydia trachomatis (D-K serotype), an obligate intracellular parasite, responsible for up to 40-60% of PID cases.

Most common route of spread: Ascending infection, often carried along with sperm.

Common sites affected:

  • Endocervix
  • Urethra
  • Bartholin's gland

Stratified squamous epithelium is resistant, like in Gonococcal infection.

Symptoms:

  • Insidious onset
  • Mostly asymptomatic
  • May present with mucopurulent cervical discharge

Diagnosis:

  • NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) - gold standard
  • PCR - highly sensitive

Treatment in pregnancy:

  • Azithromycin 1 g orally, single dose (Drug of choice) or
  • Amoxicillin 500 mg TDS for 7 days

Explanation for other options:

Gonorrhea (Option B): Also a common cause, but less frequent than Chlamydia.

Streptococcus (Option C): Rare cause, more commonly associated with postpartum or post-surgical infections.

Candida (Option D): Causes vaginitis, not pelvic inflammatory disease.

questions.text: All are the indications for admission in case of PID except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mild to Moderate abdominal pain is not an indication for admission in case of PID.

Indications for Inpatient Treatment in PID:

  • Surgical emergencies like appendicitis cannot be ruled out
  • The patient is pregnant (Option B)
  • The patient is HIV positive (Option C)
  • The patient does not respond to oral antibiotics (within 72 hours)
  • The patient is unable to follow or tolerate an outpatient oral regimen
  • Patient has severe illness, nausea and vomiting or high fever
  • The patient has a tubo-ovarian abscess (Option D)

questions.text: All are the sequelae of PID except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple pregnancy is not related to PID; more commonly linked with ART or ovulation induction.

Explanation for other options:

Ectopic pregnancy (Option A): PID can lead to scarring and damage to the fallopian tubes, increasing the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

Chronic pelvic pain (Option B): PID can cause inflammation, pelvic adhesions and scarring in the pelvic organs, leading to persistent pain.

Dyspareunia (Option D): Dyspareunia, or painful sexual intercourse, can result from the pelvic inflammation and scarring associated with PID.

questions.text: The most common route of spread of genital tuberculosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common route of spread of genital tuberculosis is hematogenous.

Genital tuberculosis is almost always a secondary infection, with the most common primary sites being the lungs > lymph nodes > and abdomen

  • The most common site is the B/L Fallopian tubes (In Fallopian tubes - most commonly affected part = Ampulla)
  • The most commonly encountered pathology is endosalpingitis
  • The most common age group affected is 20-30 years
  • The spread of endometrial TB is specifically direct spread from the tube.

questions.text: The most common site for genital tuberculosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common site for genital tuberculosis is the fallopian tube.

  • The fallopian tubes are involved in 90-100% of cases of female genital tuberculosis (FGTB), making them the most common site.
  • Tuberculous salpingitis typically starts at the mucosa, leading to tubal blockage, adhesions, and infertility.
  • The endometrium (uterus) is the second most common site, followed by the ovary and rarely the cervix and vagina.

HSG image of Fallopian TB

questions.text: The most common menstrual complaint in patients of genital TB is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common menstrual complaint is oligomenorrhea in patients of genital TB due to adhesions/atrophy in the endometrium.

Menstrual problems occurring in TB patients:

  • The most common menstrual complaint is oligomenorrhea/Amenorrhea
  • 1st menstrual complaint - Menorrhagia (due to Endometritis in acute phase)
  • Pelvic examination - most common finding = Normal pelvic examination
  • 2nd most common finding - tenderness present

choices.text: Homogeneous vaginal discharge with pH 5.0 to 6.0
Positive clue cells in 100% of cases
It is due to Gardnerella vaginalis

questions.text: Regarding bacterial vaginosis, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clue cells are diagnostic, but about 40% patients may not have clue cells.

Explanation for other options:

Homogeneous discharge with pH 5-6 (Option A): Bacterial vaginosis (BV) typically presents with thin, grayish-white discharge and a raised pH (>4.5) due to reduced lactobacilli.

Positive KOH with fishy odor (Option B): The whiff test is positive in BV, producing a fishy odor due to the release of amines when 10% KOH is added to the vaginal discharge.

Caused by Gardnerella vaginalis (Option D): BV is primarily due to the overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and anaerobic bacteria, replacing the normal lactobacilli flora.

choices.text: White, milky, nonviscous, adherent vaginal discharge

questions.text: Amsel's criteria of bacterial vaginosis include all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vaginal pH more than 4.5 in Amsel's criteria of bacterial vaginosis,

  • Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to alteration of vaginal flora; lactobacilli decrease whereas coccobacilli and Gardnerella increase. It is the most common vaginitis. Vaginal pH <5.5 in candidiasis which is mostly unaltered.

Amsel's criteria include:

  • White milky, non viscous, adherent vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH more than 4.5
  • Positive whiff test: amine odour with 10% KOH
  • Presence of clue cells
  • Increase in the number of Gardnerella vaginalis and reduced number of lactobacilli

Treatment:

  • Metronidazole 2 g single dose or tinidazole,
  • Clindamycin 300 mg BD for 7 days

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a growth on the vulva as seen in the image, the probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Condyloma acuminata:

  • It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by HPV 6, 16 and 18.
  • Warts are seen on the vulval area.
  • Warts are common in the regions affected most directly by coitus, i.e. posterior fourchette and the lateral areas of the vulva.
  • These verrucous growths may coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths.
  • Condyloma is associated with vulval, vaginal and cervical cancers.
  • Diagnosis is by colposcopy, which shows raised patches of aceto-white epithelium with a speckled appearance.

Young women with flat condylomas may be observed for 6 months, especially if they develop during pregnancy, as lesions may disappear spontaneously.

Treatment options include:

  • Podophyllin
  • Podofilox: Cannot be used in pregnancy
  • Imiquimod
  • Trichloroacetic acid: Can be applied in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy to avoid cesarean section with large lesions.
  • Electrocoagulation/Cryotherapy/Laser therapy: Can be done in pregnancy, but before 32 weeks to avoid post-treatment necrosis, which may last as long as 4-6 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the below infections of vagina occurs in acidic pH
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Candida is the most common vaginitis:

  • Pregnancy, diabetes
  • Immunocompromised
  • OCP users, steroid users, and antibiotic users

Symptoms: intense pruritus, Curdy white vaginal discharge

Signs: yeasty curdy white vaginal discharge, Cervix normal

Diagnosis: Sabouraud's media, Fungal hyphae in 10% KOH preparation, pH <4.5

Treatment: clotrimazole vaginal pessary tab. Fluconazole 150 mg single dose

questions.text: A young lady presents to your office with a complaint of copious vaginal discharge, but there is no cervical discharge on per speculum examination. Which of the following should be given for the management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metronidazole and fluconazole are the best options for this patient.

In a case where a young woman presents with copious vaginal discharge but no cervical discharge, this is suggestive of a vaginal infection rather than a cervical infection. The most common causes of vaginal discharge are:

  • Bacterial Vaginosis - treated with Metronidazole
  • Candidiasis - treated with Fluconazole
  • Trichomoniasis - treated with Metronidazole

Secnidazole is structurally related to the commonly used 5-nitroimidazoles metronidazole and tinidazole. These drugs share a common spectrum of activity against anaerobic microorganisms

Syndromic Management of STI (NACO STI/RTI Kits)

Explanation:

  • The gold standard for diagnosis is laparoscopy, which allows direct visualisation of inflamed, edematous, or pus-filled fallopian tubes (endosalpingitis), it may not be feasible to do so in all cases.
  • It is reserved only in those cases in which differential diagnosis includes salpingitis, appendicitis or ectopic pregnancy.
  • A nonresponding pelvic mass needs laparoscopic clarification.
  • Hysteroscopy may also provide confirmatory evidence for salpingitis.
  • Fallopian tube culture can be obtained laparoscopically, and recently, the hysteroscopic approach has been introduced. The specimen is obtained during hysteroscopy with a cytobrush.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with a painless ulcer in the labia majora with everted margins given in the image; Find the cause:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this case, a painless ulcer with an everted margin, as the image proves that the cause of the ulcer is syphilis (Treponema pallidum).

The most common causes of genital ulcers in young, sexually active women are:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV)
  • Treponema pallidum (syphilis)
  • Haemophilus ducreyi (chancroid).
